content.raw:
Should put the encoding string in a constant. Something like \`GENOMEDATA\_NAME\_ENCODING\`. This should be done for all instances of “latin-1”.

It’s probably also worth commenting on the choice of “latin-1” \(or ISO 8859-1\) in this case. It makes sense but it might be worth mentioning it’s the 8-bit extension on top of ascii \(7-bit\) \(which was natively used before\).

Should put the encoding string in a constant. Something like `GENOMEDATA_NAME_ENCODING`. This should be done for all instances of “latin-1”.

It’s probably also worth commenting on the choice of “latin-1” (or ISO 8859-1) in this case. It makes sense but it might be worth mentioning it’s the 8-bit extension on top of ascii (7-bit) (which was natively used before).

content.raw:
I don’t see “tokenize” used in this file outside this logic? Why is it necessary? If you’re tokenizing a file, why not use an encoding cookie according to the docs:

“`tokenize()` determines the source encoding of the file by looking for a UTF-8 BOM or encoding cookie, according to [**PEP 263**](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0263).”

content.raw:
Package: libhdf5-serial-dev (1.10.0-patch1+docs-4) [universe]
    
    transitional dummy package

[https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/libhdf5-serial-dev](https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/libhdf5-serial-dev)

This is probably not the package you want. In general, avoid workarounds like this. With system Ubuntu/Debian/Red Hat packages this stuff should work right out of the box. If it doesn’t that’s either because of a problem on our side \(as I think it is here\) or a bug that needs to be reported upstream. Changing environment variables like this leads to a lot of inconsistency, and problems with less sophisticated users installing the software, and should be a last resort.
content.html:
Package: libhdf5-serial-dev (1.10.0-patch1+docs-4) [universe]

transitional dummy package

https://packages.ubuntu.com/bionic/libhdf5-serial-dev

This is probably not the package you want. In general, avoid workarounds like this. With system Ubuntu/Debian/Red Hat packages this stuff should work right out of the box. If it doesn’t that’s either because of a problem on our side (as I think it is here) or a bug that needs to be reported upstream. Changing environment variables like this leads to a lot of inconsistency, and problems with less sophisticated users installing the software, and should be a last resort.

content.raw: OK. The question here is whether you want to read as Unicode. I think in most cases we don’t. If we do want to change the default, should add a “mode” argument and set the default there so it can be overriden.
content.html: OK. The question here is whether you want to read as Unicode. I think in most cases we don’t. If we do want to change the default, should add a “mode” argument and set the default there so it can be overriden.

content.raw:
Since the resulting read string is going to be potentially manipulated in Python, the question becomes whether or not we want to return standard Python strings or the lower level ‘bytes’ type. From Python 3 onwards it would seem to make the most sense to allow reading in as Unicode/UTF-8 since it’s encoding is equivalent to any ASCII we are reading and we can use the Python string manipulations as-is.

We could add a “mode” argument here but I would think that the default should be “rt” and not “rb”. If default ends up being “rb” then I believe almost all calls to ‘maybe\_gzip\_open’ will override it with the “rt” option.
content.html:
Since the resulting read string is going to be potentially manipulated in Python, the question becomes whether or not we want to return standard Python strings or the lower level ‘bytes’ type. From Python 3 onwards it would seem to make the most sense to allow reading in as Unicode/UTF-8 since it’s encoding is equivalent to any ASCII we are reading and we can use the Python string manipulations as-is.

We could add a “mode” argument here but I would think that the default should be “rt” and not “rb”. If default ends up being “rb” then I believe almost all calls to ‘maybe_gzip_open’ will override it with the “rt” option.

content.raw:
Isn’t `maybe_gzip_open()` used in Segway as well?

Also I keep seeing `str.encode()` called in this patch and it seems like some of this stuff should just be read in as bytes. I’m especially thinking of

    seq_array = frombuffer(seq.encode(GENOMEDATA_ENCODING), SEQ_DTYPE)

Before this we have:

1. read a huge sequence into memory, with unnecessary utf-8 decoding

This line:

1. encodes the sequence into latin-1 making a copy of it in memory
2. makes another copy into a NumPy array

I’m also concerned by the input and output encoding being different which may lead to problems with round trips.
content.html:
Isn’t maybe_gzip_open() used in Segway as well?

Also I keep seeing str.encode() called in this patch and it seems like some of this stuff should just be read in as bytes. I’m especially thinking of

seq_array = frombuffer(seq.encode(GENOMEDATA_ENCODING), SEQ_DTYPE)

Before this we have:

  1. read a huge sequence into memory, with unnecessary utf-8 decoding

This line:

  1. encodes the sequence into latin-1 making a copy of it in memory
  2. makes another copy into a NumPy array

I’m also concerned by the input and output encoding being different which may lead to problems with round trips.

content.raw: I seemed simpler to only deal with strings in Python, since there seemed to be several outside functions called which only handled str not bytes. So I thought it was better to have everything as strings in python, ideally converting immediately after the files have been read and before they’re written. In the seq\_array case you mentioned, that conversion back to bytes happens immediately before it is written to an HDF5 file and the new byte string is not used afterwards.
content.html: I seemed simpler to only deal with strings in Python, since there seemed to be several outside functions called which only handled str not bytes. So I thought it was better to have everything as strings in python, ideally converting immediately after the files have been read and before they’re written. In the seq_array case you mentioned, that conversion back to bytes happens immediately before it is written to an HDF5 file and the new byte string is not used afterwards.

content.raw: A warning will appear because we close the genome without calling close data in the context manager. The same issue was occurring in Python 2 however, unittest was apparently masking it. The same thing is being done where the warnings would also appear in Python 2 in a few places, such as in load\_seq at line 243, albeit without a context manager.
content.html: A warning will appear because we close the genome without calling close data in the context manager. The same issue was occurring in Python 2 however, unittest was apparently masking it. The same thing is being done where the warnings would also appear in Python 2 in a few places, such as in load_seq at line 243, albeit without a context manager.

Why is the genome closed without calling close data in the context manager?  
  
`_load_seq.py` line 243 has a note above it saying that it should probably be fixed?
content.html:
Why is the genome closed without calling close data in the context manager?

content.raw:
The load_seq case was the one we discussed in the lab meeting two weeks
ago, where you said it should be ignored because we'll never close it
immediately afterwards since we know an open_seq command is about to be
called. Similarly in these test cases, we are not using the main genomedata
functions (load-assembly, close-data, erase-data, load-data and open-data)
so the warnings appear because we are not using the functions as intended,
if I understand it correctly.
content.html: The load_seq case was the one we discussed in the lab meeting two weeks ago, where you said it should be ignored because we'll never close it immediately afterwards since we know an open_seq command is about to be called. Similarly in these test cases, we are not using the main genomedata functions (load-assembly, close-data, erase-data, load-data and open-data) so the warnings appear because we are not using the functions as intended, if I understand it correctly.

content.raw: But gzip\_open defaults to rb, so I thought it was better to make sure that the function was returning a consistent type.

content.raw: I checked and you are correct, both in Python 2 and Python 3 it defaults to `rb`. Why is the default changed here? `rt` returns a string-oriented object in Python 3 I believe but it’s not clear what it does in Python 2.
content.html: I checked and you are correct, both in Python 2 and Python 3 it defaults to rb. Why is the default changed here? rt returns a string-oriented object in Python 3 I believe but it’s not clear what it does in Python 2.

content.raw: The default was changed so that we could read in as a str, rather than having to decode it later. Opening in rt will cause problems on windows systems, due to how they handle the bytes and text conversion, however as far as I can tell should behave the same as r on Linux.
content.html: The default was changed so that we could read in as a str, rather than having to decode it later. Opening in rt will cause problems on windows systems, due to how they handle the bytes and text conversion, however as far as I can tell should behave the same as r on Linux.

content.raw:
I'm a little confused by this refactor. Some questions:

\* What does the \`chromosome\` flag represent?

\* It looks like there’s two separate things that happen here. One section is for adding the trackname the other is for creating room for continuous data if the chromosome flag is set. If the trackname addition \\\(first section\\\) is the only part that has to deal with the encoding, why were both parts moved here? 

\* Why not just move trackname decoding specific code here and use it in the old \`\_add\_track\_continuous\` that was removed? ‌
content.html:
I'm a little confused by this refactor. Some questions:

* What does the `chromosome` flag represent?

* It looks like there’s two separate things that happen here. One section is for adding the trackname the other is for creating room for continuous data if the chromosome flag is set. If the trackname addition \(first section\) is the only part that has to deal with the encoding, why were both parts moved here?

* Why not just move trackname decoding specific code here and use it in the old `_add_track_continuous` that was removed? ‌
